pageContext.title: Panic ensues as millions of Ofo riders demand refunds
pageContext.content:
Troubled bike-share startup Ofo, which has been quitting cities around the planet this year, has a fresh crisis – millions of people are demanding their deposits back.

Ofo’s app shows that in excess of 8 million people are in a virtual queue to get back their deposits, which typically vary from US$15 to $30, depending on the date of signup.

This has been verified by numerous tech bloggers and media outlets, who have seen varying numbers over the past few days, such as this one from earlier in the day showing 7,605,947 ahead in line:

It’s not just virtual queues

At Ofo’s Beijing headquarters yesterday and today, dozens of people formed a line that started out on the street.

Photo credit: 乐活北京 WeChat account

At least five police vehicles were seen at the scene yesterday.

The Ofo users snaked across the building’s plaza…

Photo credit: 乐活北京 WeChat account

Through the lobby…

Photo credit: 乐活北京 WeChat account

And along corridors, all the way into the startup’s offices.

Photo credit: 乐活北京 WeChat account

Tech in Asia has not received a reply from Ofo on enquiries made this morning.

Ofo has vowed to refund all applications – whether online or in-person – in order of receipt, reported China Daily this afternoon.

In addition to that brouhaha, Ofo’s website is not online right now, with website tracker Is It Down Right Now reporting it’s been offline for more than a week.

Both Ofo and archrival Mobike – the two biggest players – have left a number of cities in the past year, reversing a period of rapid growth fueled by billions of dollars in investor cash.

Late last year, China’s third largest bike-share startup, Bluegogo, went bust shortly after finding itself unable to refund a rush of user deposits.

“Our deposits are safely stored and overseen by CITIC Bank,” an Ofo spokesperson told Tech in Asia at the time of Bluegogo’s demise.

seo.title: Millions of Ofo riders in rush to demand deposit refund
seo.description: Big trouble for the bike-share app.
